#Text=Samuel Zborowski
#Text=Samuel Zborowski ( died 1584 ) was a Polish military commander and a notable member of the szlachta ( Polish nobility ) .

#Text=He is best remembered for having been executed by supporters of the Polish king Stefan Batory and chancellor Jan Zamoyski ; an event which caused much uproar among the contemporary Polish nobility .
#Text=Biography
#Text=Son of Marcin Zborowski and brother to Andrzej , Jan , Krzysztof and Piotr , Samuel was an heir of a significant fortune within Poland .

#Text=His family was notable for its wealth and influence at the royal court of Poland , his father was a castellan of Kraków and his brother Jan was a personal secretary of the king Sigismund II of Poland and one of the most influential people of the epoch .
#Text=Zborowski rose to the power of a Royal rotmistrz at the court of Sigismund II .
#Text=The title , quite prestigious at the time , was seen as a base for further titles and powers .
#Text=After Sigismund 's death and the election of Henry III de Valois as the next King of Poland , a tournament was held at the Wawel Castle in honour of the new monarch on 23 February 1574 .
#Text=Zborowski had the honour of throwing his gauntlet as the first knight , yet his proposal of a fight was not responded by any respectable nobleman .
#Text=Instead , the goblet was raised by certain Karwat , one of non-noble soldiers of the castellan of Wojnice Jan Tęczyński .
#Text=After Karwat defeated Zborowski 's servant in a duel , Zborowski felt this as a serious offence and attacked Tęczyński himself , in the presence of a new monarch .
#Text=Castellan of Przemyśl Andrzej Wapowski tried to calm down the fighters , but was hit with Zborowski 's mace and was badly hurt .
#Text=Wapowski refused to rest and instead started a campaign against Zborowski ; his wound got infected and he died a week later .

#Text=Although a murder committed during a Sejm ( Polish parliament ) or in presence of a monarch was punishable by death , the new king did not want to start conflicts with the mighty family of Zborowski and sentenced him to banishment , without infamy .
#Text=Zborowski fled Poland even before the verdict was presented and joined the court of Stefan Batory , then the Prince of Transylvania .
#Text=After several months Henry III renounced his kingship of Poland in favour of the kingship of France .
#Text=Three years afterwards Batory was elected his successor .

#Text=Zborowski returned to Poland , expecting that his brothers , some of the most notable supporters of Batory 's candidacy , would raise to even greater fame and wealth after the new monarch arrived .
#Text=However , most of the important offices were taken by the supporters of Jan Zamoyski and the Zborowski brothers gradually lost importance .
#Text=This made them enemies of the new king and two of them , namely Andrzej and Krzysztof , started to plot with the courts of Moscow and Vienna against the life of the monarch .

#Text=Samuel tried to rehabilitate himself by raising a Cossack regiment and taking part in the war against Muscovy and the Velikiye Luki ( Wielkie Łuki ) Campaign of 1580 , where he proved to be a courageous warrior .
#Text=However , the sentence was not changed and the Zborowskis received no reward or recognition for their efforts .

#Text=Samuel then moved to Dzikie Pola region where he was a celebrity among the Cossacks ; together they carried several raids against the Ottoman Empire , angering king Batory , who wanted to pursue a policy of appeasement with Ottomans .

#Text=In 1584 Wojciech Długoraj , a notable composer and virtuoso lutenist in Zborowski 's service who was maltreated by him , turned several incriminating letters written between the Zborowski brothers ( Krzysztof and Samuel ) to their enemy Jan Zamoyski .
#Text=In these letters they described their preparations for the assassination of the king .
#Text=Batory told Zamoyski that Zborowski should be executed ; however as he had no power to issue such an order , Zamoyski would act on the basis of the 1574 banishment sentence .
#Text=In May 1584 Zborowski entered the area of Lesser Poland ( Małopolska ) , which was then under jurisdiction of Jan Zamoyski .
#Text=He was arrested in Piekary and executed on 26 May 1584 at the Wawel hill by beheading .
#Text=Długoraj was forced to flee to Germany for fear of Zborowski 's heirs , who swore revenge .

#Text=Despite the fact that the execution was fully lawful , it was seen by many of the szlachta , most notably by the Protestants , as an act of vengeance or abuse of monarch power , a warning to the dangers of absolutism ( especially pronounced given the power of Poland 's nobility , amounting to a quasi-democracy ) .
#Text=Zborowski would be remembered by many as a martyr .
#Text=His brothers moved to avenge him and tried to gain support from other nobles .

#Text=At the November 1585 local sejmik , Krzysztof Zborowski and his men filled the church where the meeting was to take place ( and where Zamoyski was to appear ) and disrupted the proceedings with brandished weapons , openly calling for the other nobles to hand over Zamoyski .
#Text=The proceedings were moved to the graveyard , where Zborowski proceeded to " filibuster " by ringing the church bell .

#Text=Two different marshals were elected at the meeting , one by Zborowski 's supporters and one by the opposition , and resolutions were only slowly passed , one of which asked the national Sejm to consider the legality of Zamoyski executing Zborowski .
#Text=Earlier that year , at the Sejm of January 1585 two of Zborowski 's brothers were tried for their plans and Krzysztof was banished .
#Text=During the proceedings , evidence against Krzysztof Zborowski amounted , including a letter in which he discussed killing the king .
#Text=Bathory summoned Krzysztof to appear , but he did not .
#Text=The second Zborowski was convicted of treason and sentenced to death .
#Text=This finally broke the power of the once mighty family .
